title: Liberty's boys soccer champs back in the spotlight, 40 years later
text:
Liberty's 1975 state championship team will be honored at halftime of the Hurricanes' game against Freedom on Thursday. (lehighvalleylive.com file photo) By Kyle Craig | For lehighvalleylive.com on October 14, 2015 7:00 AM, updated October 14, 2015 5:12 PM 
Few, if any, areas in the state can match the boys soccer prowess that Bethlehem exhibited when the PIAA began crowning state champions in the early 1970s. 
A large part of that rich history will be recognized on Thursday night. 
The 1975 Liberty High School state championship team will be on hand when the current Hurricanes play Freedom 7:15 p.m. Thursday at Bethlehem Area School District Stadium. 
The 1975 squad will be highlighted with a ceremony during halftime of the rivalry clash, honoring the 40th anniversary of its 1-0 triumph over North Allegheny. 
Former Hurricanes coach Jim Kennedy said 21 members of the title-winning team will be on hand, traveling from points across the entire country (California, Texas, Florida). 
Kennedy reminisced about the 1975 season earlier this week, recalling how the Hurricanes knocked off Freedom, Palisades, Delaware Valley and Hempfield en route to their gold-medal evening in Reading. 
The celebration for Liberty’s triumph? Potts’ Doggie Shop on Fairview Street stayed open late and the players stuffed themselves with all the hot dogs they could eat. 
“All these memories are going to come back and everyone is so excited for this,” Kennedy said. 
The 1975 team was inducted into Liberty’s Athletic Hall of Fame in January, allowing a smaller contingent of past players to gather again on Linden Street. 
“Everybody was so excited to see each other,” Kennedy said. “It was just great. It’s interesting to see how much the kids have changed.” 
There was no shortage of fine players on that Hurricanes squad, of course, including Jim Stamatis, who won the Hermann Trophy (soccer's version of the Heisman Trophy) at Penn State and played professionally, Keith Jones, a captain who was lost to a broken leg, John Shireman and sophomore leading scorer Joey Kovacs. 
After Liberty’s triumph in ’75, Freedom had a runner-up finish in 1976; the Hurricanes placed second in 1977; and Freedom earned a co-state championship in 1983 after playing to a 16-overtime tie with Trinity. 
District 11 didn’t celebrate another champion until Moravian Academy captured the Class A title last season. 
Kennedy credits Bethlehem’s early success in the sport to the infrastructure and development provided by the Greater Bethlehem Youth Soccer League, a product of influential figures like Dr. Tom Fleck, Ed Csongradi and Charlie Garcia. 
The Christmas City soccer formula didn’t stay unique to Bethlehem for long. 
“The greatest form of flattery is imitation,” said Kennedy, who retired from teaching at Liberty in 1999. “They (other Lehigh Valley schools) caught on and all of a sudden club soccer caught on like crazy.” 
This year’s Liberty team isn’t doing badly for itself, either. The Hurricanes are 16-1 and the No. 2 team in the area, according to lehighvalleylive. Kennedy is excited to see Liberty in person. 
“They are for real,” he said. “They have a really good team; they’re fast; they’re talented … It should be a great game.” 
And a fitting night to honor a great team.
